node.contents: If you have complex mapping i would recommend to stick to Java serialization itself, You can store object state using JDBC for example using hibernate, but that requires complex mappings to be done which will further complicate your situation.

node.contents: The unsafe field is your instance of Unsafe. If you don't know how to get it, simply use:

astNode.text: The unsafe field is your instance of Unsafe. If you don't know how to get it, simply use:

elements.contents: Unsafe unsafe = getUnsafe(); Unsafe getUnsafe() { try { Field f = Unsafe.class.getDeclaredField("theUnsafe"); f.setAccessible(true); return (Unsafe) f.get(null); } catch (Exception x) { x.printStackTrace(); } return null; }

units.rawText: Unsafe unsafe = getUnsafe(); Unsafe getUnsafe() { try { Field f = Unsafe.class.getDeclaredField("theUnsafe"); f.setAccessible(true); return (Unsafe) f.get(null); } catch (Exception x) { x.printStackTrace(); } return null; }

node.contents: Keep in mind this should work for HotSpot JVM since the field name differs across different implementations.

astNode.text: Keep in mind this should work for HotSpot JVM since the field name differs across different implementations.

node.contents: You can move objects off the heap by:

astNode.text: You can move objects off the heap by:

node.contents: 1) Allocate the proper bytes to the memory address. You can read the int at the offset 4L, convert to unsigned long, and add 12L, and get the address at that location.

astNode.text: 1) Allocate the proper bytes to the memory address. You can read the int at the offset 4L, convert to unsigned long, and add 12L, and get the address at that location.

node.contents: An example implementation:

astNode.text: An example implementation:

elements.contents: public static long sizeOf(Object object) { return unsafe.getAddress( normalize( unsafe.getInt(object, 4L) ) + 12L ); } public static long normalize(int value) { if(value >= 0) return value; return (~0L >>> 32) & value; }

units.rawText: public static long sizeOf(Object object) { return unsafe.getAddress( normalize( unsafe.getInt(object, 4L) ) + 12L); } public static long normalize(int value) { if(value >= 0) return value; return (~0L >>> 32) & value; }

node.contents: You can allocate the offheap space using:

astNode.text: You can allocate the offheap space using:

elements.contents: Object object = // Your object long size = sizeOf(object); long address = unsafe.allocateMemory(size);

units.rawText: Object object = // Your object long size = sizeOf(object); long address = unsafe.allocateMemory(size);

node.contents: (Keep the address field handy)

astNode.text: (Keep the address field handy)

node.contents: 2) Copy the object into the memory section specified by the address .

astNode.text: 2) Copy the object into the memory section specified by the address .

node.contents: Done! Now your object is offheap.

node.contents: To get your object back, simply execute following:

astNode.text: To get your object back, simply execute following:

elements.contents: // Class wide field Object anchor; // Deserializarion long offset = unsafe.objectFieldOffset(this.getClass().getDeclaredField("anchor")); unsafe.putLong(this, offset, address);

comments.text: // Deserializarion long offset = unsafe.objectFieldOffset(this.getClass().getDeclaredField("anchor")); unsafe.putLong(this, offset, address);

units.rawText: // Class wide field Object anchor; // Deserializarion long offset = unsafe.objectFieldOffset(this.getClass().getDeclaredField("anchor")); unsafe.putLong(this, offset, address);

node.contents: Then, anchor should be your Object from offheap!
